forum.name: Thoughts for Successful Number Talks
forum.intro:
In Session 3.1, you experienced a number talk as a learner and also discussed the learner benefits of this instructional routine. In this activity, you will read an excerpt from the book Making Number Talks Matter (2015). The authors, Cathy Humphreys and Ruth Parker, share tips for doing number talks for the first time with learners based on their experience using number talks with their students. This book focuses on grades 4–10; however, the messages are still relevant and important for adult learners. One of the goals of number talks is for learners to build a solid foundation on number sense and the role of operations. This instructional routine puts sense-making and divergent learner thinking at the center of a mathematics discussion. Thought processes are visible to all so that every participant has opportunities to build flexible thinking and a deeper understanding of numbers and operations.

  1. Read pages 18–24 of the chapter Thoughts for Successful Number Talks from Making Number Talks Matter (Humphreys & Parker, 2015).[1]
  2. Share your thoughts in the discussion forum below. Click ADD DISCUSSION TOPIC to add a post to the forum. Respond to the following prompts:
    • What are ways that conceptual knowledge and procedural fluency come into play with number talk experiences?
    • What are one or two instructional moves you would like to remember when implementing number talks?
  3. Read and respond to others’ postings. (Click “Discuss this topic” on an individual post, then click “Reply” to respond to that post.)

[1] Humphreys, C. & Parker, R. (2015). Making number talks matter: Developing mathematical practices and deepening understanding, grades 4–10. Stenhouse Publishers.
